comments:
I am developing a project where we are evaluating to use the Boost
(www.boost.org) uBlas library. 

When I include the header "boost/numeric/ublas/matrix.hpp" and save the project,
the entire GUI locks completely. (The hourglass spins around, but no redraws are
done on Eclipse.) This happens even in the simplest "Hello world" project.

Eclipse's Java process uses 100% CPU. I have let it run for 10 minutes to see if
it is just the slow indexer, but nothing happens. I have also tried to turn of
indexing and hinting.
What version of the Boost libraries are you using?

I do not see the bug using the latest out of CVS. 
Please retry w/a recent build. 
http://download.eclipse.org/tools/cdt/builds/2.0.2/I200409101437/index.html

Thanks

I am using boost 1.31

With I200409101437 I get a "Saved failed : Null" message when I include the
header. This message comes after ~5 seconds of inactivity.

It saves correctly when I leave the header out.

My workspace/.metadata/.log file says:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 4 sep 15, 2004 09:09:33.523
!MESSAGE Save Failed
 
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 2 0 sep 15, 2004 09:09:33.529
!MESSAGE Save Failed
!STACK 0
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError


BTW. I found no documentation on how to install a build from zipfiles, so I
deleted/uninstalled 2.0.1 as described in the FAQ, and then extracted the 2.0.2
build into the correct place. Plug In Details now show I have version 2.0.2
installed.

Go to Window->Preferences
Select C++ on the LHS of the pane
On the RHS of the pane, do you have "Follow #include's when producing the 
outline view" selected?
If so, deselect it.  
The Boost libraries are template-heavy and unfortunately our parser has a bit 
of trouble with it. 
I found that I needed to start Eclipse w/512MB of RAM just to get content 
assist to not crash the file that includes matrix.hpp.

Yes, I did have "Follow #include's when producing the outline view" enabled. By
deselecting it I am now able to save the file properly.

Thanks for the info.  
I'm going to keep this defect open until I can fix our memory scalability 
issues.

Andrew, can you investigate this for 3.0.  
We get an NPE somewhere deep in template land when we index this file.
